ai-mn66:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Northern Āpaṇas, where they have a town called Āpaṇa.
ai-mn66:2.1_0: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Āpaṇa for alms.
ai-mn66:2.2_0: He wandered for alms in Āpaṇa. After the meal, on his return from alms-round, he went to a certain forest grove for the day’s meditation.

ai-mn66:3.4_0: Then as Venerable Udāyī was in private retreat this thought came to his mind:
ai-mn66:4.1_0: “The Buddha has rid us of so many things that bring suffering and gifted us so many things that bring happiness!
ai-mn66:4.2_0: He has rid us of so many unskillful things and gifted us so many skillful things!”
ai-mn66:5.1_0: Then in the late afternoon, Udāyī came out of retreat and went to the Buddha.
ai-mn66:5.1_2: He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:
ai-mn66:6.1_0: “Just now, sir, as I was in private retreat this thought came to mind.
ai-mn66:6.2_0: ‘The Buddha has rid us of so many things that bring suffering and gifted us so many things that bring happiness!
ai-mn66:6.3_0: He has rid us of so many unskillful things and gifted us so many skillful things!’
ai-mn66:6.4_0: For we used to eat in the evening, the morning, and at the wrong time of day.
ai-mn66:6.5_0: There he a time when the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
ai-mn66:6.6_0: ‘Please, mendicants, give up that meal at the wrong time of day.’
ai-mn66:6.7_0: At that, sir, we became sad and upset,
ai-mn66:6.8_0: ‘But these faithful householders give us a variety of delicious foods at the wrong time of day. And the Blessed One tells us to give it up! The Holy One tells us to let it go!’
ai-mn66:6.9_0: But when we considered our love and respect for the Buddha, and our sense of conscience and prudence, we gave up that meal at the wrong time of day.
ai-mn66:6.10_0: Then we ate in the evening and the morning.
ai-mn66:6.11_0: There he a time when the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
ai-mn66:6.12_0: ‘Please, mendicants, give up that meal at the wrong time of night.’
ai-mn66:6.13_0: At that, sir, we became sad and upset,
ai-mn66:6.14_0: ‘But that’s considered the more delicious of the two meals. And the Blessed One tells us to give it up! The Holy One tells us to let it go!’
ai-mn66:6.15_0: Once it so happened that a certain person got some soup during the day. He said,
ai-mn66:6.16_0: ‘Come, let’s set this aside; we’ll enjoy it together this evening.’
ai-mn66:6.17_0: Nearly all meals are prepared at night, only a few in the day.
ai-mn66:6.18_0: But when we considered our love and respect for the Buddha, and our sense of conscience and prudence, we gave up that meal at the wrong time of night.
ai-mn66:6.19_0: In the past, mendicants went wandering for alms in the dark of the night. They walked into a swamp, or fell into a sewer, or collided with a thorn bush, or collided with a sleeping cow, or encountered youths escaping a crime or on their way to commit one, or were invited by a female to commit a lewd act.
ai-mn66:6.20_0: Once it so happened that I wandered for alms in the dark of the night.
ai-mn66:6.21_0: A woman washing a pot saw me by a flash of lightning.
ai-mn66:6.24_0: When she said this, I said to her,
ai-mn66:6.27_0: ‘Then it’s a mendicant whose ma died and pa died!
ai-mn66:6.28_0: You’d be better off having your belly sliced open with a meat cleaver than to wander for alms in the dark of night for the sake of your belly.’
ai-mn66:6.30_0: ‘The Buddha has rid us of so many things that bring suffering and gifted us so many things that bring happiness!
ai-mn66:6.31_0: He has rid us of so many unskillful things and gifted us so many skillful things!’”

ai-mn66:7.2_0: ‘But what’s the point of this minor matter?’
ai-mn66:7.3_0: They don’t burn upright, wriggling, and have no reason for me.

ai-mn66:8.6_0: For that quail, that vine is a strong, firm, stout bond, a tie that has not rotted, and a heavy yoke.”

ai-mn66:13.1_0: Udāyī, these four people are found in the world.
ai-mn66:13.2_0: What four? A person may have:
ai-mn66:14.1_0: Take a certain person practicing to give up and let go of attachments.
ai-mn66:14.2_0: The letting go of attachments, and giving up attachments.
ai-mn66:14.3_0: They tolerate them and don’t give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them.
ai-mn66:14.6_0: For the diversity of faculties I understand this person’s faculties.
ai-mn66:15.1_0: Take a certain person practicing to give up and let go of attachments.
ai-mn66:15.2_0: The letting go of attachments, and giving up attachments.
ai-mn66:15.3_0: They don’t tolerate them, but give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them.
ai-mn66:15.6_0: For the diversity of faculties I understand this person’s faculties.
ai-mn66:16.1_0: Take a certain person practicing to give up and let go of attachments.
ai-mn66:16.2_0: The letting go of attachments, the giving up of attachments, and the ending of attachments.
ai-mn66:16.4_0: but they quickly give up, get rid of, eliminate, and obliterate those thoughts.
ai-mn66:16.5_0: Suppose there was an iron cauldron that had been heated all day, and a person let two or three drops of water fall onto it.
ai-mn66:16.6_0: The drops would be slow to fall, but they’d quickly dry up and evaporate.
ai-mn66:16.7_0: In the same way, take a person practicing to give up and let go of attachments.
ai-mn66:16.8_0: The letting go of attachments, the giving up of attachments, and the ending of attachments.

ai-mn66:17.5_0: For the diversity of faculties I understand this person’s faculties.
ai-mn66:17.6_0: These are the four people found in the world.
ai-mn66:18.1_0: Udāyī, these are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
ai-mn66:18.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
ai-mn66:18.3_0: Sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-mn66:18.4_0: There are sounds known by the ear ...
ai-mn66:18.7_0: Touches known by the body that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-mn66:18.8_0: These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
ai-mn66:19.1_0: The pleasure and happiness that arise from these five kinds of sensual stimulation is called sensual pleasure—a filthy, ordinary, ignoble pleasure.
ai-mn66:20.1_0: Take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption ...
ai-mn66:20.4_0: Giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
ai-mn66:21.1_0: This is called the pleasure of renunciation, the pleasure of seclusion, the pleasure of peace, the pleasure of awakening.
ai-mn66:21.1_1: ‘This is not appropriate for me to say.’

ai-mn66:30.1_0: Take a mendicant who, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the ending of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space. That goes beyond it.
ai-mn66:31.1_0: Take a mendicant who, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite consciousness. That goes beyond it.
ai-mn66:32.1_0: Take a mendicant who, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness. That goes beyond it.
ai-mn66:33.1_0: Take a mendicant who, going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, enters and remains in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. That goes beyond it.
ai-mn66:34.1_0: Take a mendicant who, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, enters and remains in the cessation of perception and feeling. That goes beyond it.
ai-mn66:34.2_0: So, Udāyī, I even recommend giving up the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
ai-mn66:34.3_0: Do you see any fetter, large or small, that I don’t recommend giving up?”
ai-mn66:34.5_0: This is what the Buddha said.
ai-mn66:34.6_0: Satisfied, Venerable Udāyī was happy with what the Buddha said.
